abstract.t: This specification defines a means for a client, representing a requesting party, to obtain authorization from an OAuth 2.0 authorization server. Once authorized, it defines means for that client to obtain access tokens to any protected resources that trust the authorization server. This access is granted dynamically, potentially after initial authorization, effectively putting the client into a mode of continuous authorization.

section.title: Introduction
section.t:
OAuth defines the refresh token in section 1.5 as:
A refresh token is a string representing the authorization granted to the client by the resource owner.
This profile extends the meaning of this to include a requesting party.

The value of the scope parameter is expressed as a list of space- delimited, case-sensitive strings. The strings are defined by the authorization server.
Section 3.3. This specificatin clarifies this to state that the scope is defined by the resource server
the authorization server authenticates the resource owner and obtains an authorization decision (by asking the resource owner or by establishing approval via other means) section 4.1.1

The scope of the access request as described by Section 3.3. The requested scope MUST NOT include any scope not originally granted by the resource owner, and if omitted is treated as equal to the scope originally granted by the resource owner.
Section 6.
This specification clarifies "originally granted", chiefly to remove the constraint. This is in acknowledgement that the resource owner's grant can change dynamically at any time, either to decrease _or_ increase the scope of access.
The refresh token is bound to the client and requesting party.
